title: WIKITONGUES: Hannah speaking Oshiwambo
content: Good evening, my name is Hannah and I'm talking to you from Namibia. I was born in Onandjokwe Hospital in Ondangwa, but I grew up in Walvis Bay. I now live and work in Windhoek Namibia's capital city. Now let me briefly tell you how it is like where I'm from. Where I am from we have Omakale and Omindonga. What do we eat? We eat a vegetable called ekaka we eat pearl millet flour we also eat worms from the Mopane tree. We farm with cattle, goats and chicken. What I love most about my place of birth is the chicken and porridge made with pearly millet flour. Subtitles by the Amara.org community
sentences: Good evening, my name is Hannah and I'm talking to you from Namibia.
I was born in Onandjokwe Hospital in Ondangwa, but I grew up in Walvis Bay.
I now live and work in Windhoek Namibia's capital city.
Now let me briefly tell you how it is like where I'm from.
Where I am from we have Omakale and Omindonga.
What do we eat?
We eat a vegetable called ekaka we eat pearl millet flour we also eat worms from the Mopane tree.
We farm with cattle, goats and chicken.
What I love most about my place of birth is the chicken and porridge made with pearly millet flour.
Subtitles by the Amara.org community

title: Owambo Culture: Language
content: This is for those who will be learning Oshikwanyama What am I? What would you call me? "Dinner's ready"- what would you tell me? How do you say "OK"? How do you say "Spinach" What do you want, Michael? Are you going to teach me too? Can you show me how to count? How do I say "thank you" Oh, it's just like Afrikaans, almost. Tangi! Ok now sing it, sing it! Ah, keep going! [Kids sing in Oshikwanyama]
sentences: This is for those who will be learning Oshikwanyama What am I?
What would you call me?
"Dinner's ready"- what would you tell me?
How do you say "OK"?
How do you say "Spinach" What do you want, Michael?
Are you going to teach me too?
Can you show me how to count?
How do I say "thank you" Oh, it's just like Afrikaans, almost.
Tangi!
Ok now sing it, sing it!
Ah, keep going!
[Kids sing in Oshikwanyama]

What am I? What would you call me?

How do you say "OK"?
How do you say "Spinach"
What do you want, Michael? Are you going to teach me too?
Can you show me how to count?
How do I say "thank you"
Oh, it's just like Afrikaans, almost.
Tangi!
Ok now sing it, sing it!
Ah, keep going!
[Kids sing in Oshikwanyama]
